Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Robust and Secure Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cognitive radio is a promising paradigm for dramatically increasing the utilization of wireless spectrum to support the continuing exponential growth in wireless traffic. Research on cognitive networks has mainly focused on sensing of spectrum opportunities and managing radio resources such that the primary users' quality of service is not compromised. Much less attention has been paid to the coexistence of secondary users, which may be associated with different cognitive networks and seek to operate in the same frequency bands. Effective coexistence of such users is essential for the success of future cognitive networks, and is the main objective of this project. In addition, the particularly open nature of cognitive radio raises significant new issues for the security and privacy of the transmitted data, as well as new opportunities for malicious behavior among cognitive or outside entities. The project addresses all of these issues in a holistic framework.

Coexistence requires effective allocation of radio resources in time, frequency, and space among multiple cognitive secondary users, while respecting primary interference constraints. The investigators are developing theoretical bounds for such radio resource management schemes and designing low-overhead distributed algorithms, which account for the incentives of competing secondary service providers as well as the stronger security and privacy measures needed in a cognitive environment. Information-theoretic physical-layer security techniques are being utilized to develop provably secure paradigms for secondary cognitive users and game-theoretic models are being adapted to study the robustness of these networks to various jamming attacks and other malicious behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has studied wireless cognitive radio networks, where the wireless nodes continually measure the spectrum to determine its availability and utilize unused spectrum for communication. Such flexible, demand-based, adaptive access to spectrum improves the utilization of available spectrum. However, in order for users to co-exist peacefully in this open spectrum, they should implement careful resource allocation algorithms in order not to create unacceptable amounts of interference for one another. In addition, the particularly open nature of this communication medium necessitates the use of strong security mechanisms. This project developed such resource allocation and security mechanisms for wireless cognitive radio networks.


The major technical outcome of this project is the development of distributed radio resource allocation algorithms and information-theoretic physical layer security mechanisms for cognitive networks composed of single and multi-antenna transmitters and receivers. Both the radio resource allocation algorithms and physical layer security mechanisms are developed under practical system conditions where the channel qualities of the users may not be known completely. The radio resource allocation algorithms are run distributedly by the users under partial system information. The physical layer security mechanisms provide information-theoretic unconditional security guarantees.


Educational and outreach outcomes of this project include the development of a graduate-level course on wireless physical layer security at the University of Maryland, and offering of several tutorials at international conferences and summer schools.


Human development and training outcomes of this project include training of several PhD students here at Maryland, and at Northwestern, Oulu and Aalto (our collaborative partners in this project) on physical layer security, resource allocation, optimization, wireless communication theory, and network information theory. These PhD students have had the opportunity of interacting with their peers and other professors at different institutions through this project, which enhanced their learning and research experiences.
